body:
@dreambit default training is done with a mosaic dataloader, in which case the size of your images is irrelevant. See https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov3#image-augmentation

If you want to disable the mosaic dataloader, you can use rectangular training with --img-size 608, which will pad images to the minimum 32 multiple on the short side, but this is not recommended, as you will get worse results.
@glenn-jocher Can we use non-square custom **network size** (f.e. 608x320) during training?

@AlexeyAB yes you can train on rectangular images with the --rect flag. The long side is defined by --img-size, the short side by the min 32-multiple pad necessary to accommodate all images in the batch.
```
python3 train.py --img-size 416 --rect
```
![train_batch0 (1)](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/26833433/76357202-80b29f00-62d4-11ea-92d6-e7a211cd230b.png)

Rectangular testing and inference are already switched on by default here, but training is done using a mosaic square shape:
```
python3 train.py --img-size 416
```
![train_batch0](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/26833433/76357112-506b0080-62d4-11ea-90b4-b28d290dddbd.png)

> the short side by the min 32-multiple pad necessary to accommodate all images in the batch.

Does it mean that I can't manually set width=608 and height=320 of network size forcibly for training?

@AlexeyAB not from the command line, but you could hard code those in the python code if you really wanted to.

Or you could supply a dataset of 100% images of that aspect ratio and then --rect would always do the same shape. For example if you train on 1080p video stills, then your ratio is 16:9, and if you specify --img-size 608 --rect then the network input size for the short side would always be 608*9/16 = 342, rounded up = 352 (5 pixels of padding top and bottom), so all of your batches would be shaped 640x352. It's really the most efficient way, because any other method will increase the letterbox padding.
This issue is stale because it has been open 30 days with no activity. Remove Stale label or comment or this will be closed in 5 days.

I understand that I have control over the image sizes in my dataset. But I was just wondering why do the heights and widths need to be multiples of 64. For example a 16:9 image, the height always gets padded to come to the ceiling 64 multiple. Let's say I have a 1920x1080 image, if I pass 320 as imgsz_test, then the test image gets height padded to have 320x192 dimensions. I just want to test without any padding (320x180).
@anisaha1 if you want to test without padding you'll need to supply a 64-multiple image directly.
